reauth_confirm.title: Reauthenticate Tibber Price Integration
reauth_confirm.description:
The access token for Tibber is no longer valid. Please enter a new API access token to continue using this integration.

To generate a new API access token, visit https://developer.tibber.com.

error.auth: The Tibber Access Token is invalid.
error.connection: Unable to connect to Tibber. Please check your internet connection.
error.missing_homes: The new access token does not have access to all configured homes. Please use an access token that has access to the same Tibber homes.
error.home_already_configured: This home is already configured in another entry. Each home can only be configured once.
error.no_active_subscription: This home does not have an active Tibber contract. Only homes with active electricity contracts can be added to Home Assistant.
error.subscription_expired: The Tibber contract for this home has expired. Only homes with active or future electricity contracts can be added to Home Assistant.
error.future_subscription_warning: Note: This home's Tibber contract has not started yet. Functionality may be limited until the contract becomes active.
error.invalid_yaml_syntax: Invalid YAML syntax. Please check indentation, colons, and special characters.
error.invalid_yaml_structure: YAML must be a dictionary/object (key: value pairs), not a list or plain text.
error.missing_entry_id: Entry ID is required but was not provided.
error.invalid_entry_id: Invalid entry ID or entry not found.
error.missing_home_id: Home ID is missing from the configuration entry.
error.user_data_not_available: User data is not available. Please refresh user data first.
error.price_fetch_failed: Failed to fetch price data. Please check logs for details.

abort.already_configured: All available Tibber homes are already configured. Each home can only be configured once.
abort.setup_complete: Setup complete! You can change additional options for Tibber Prices in the integration's options after closing this dialog.
abort.reauth_successful: Reauthentication successful. The integration has been updated with the new access token.

user.title: Select Configuration Entry
user.description:
Select the configuration entry for which you want to create a time-travel view.

**Time-travel views** allow you to see historical price data as if it were the current time. This is useful for testing automations or analyzing past price patterns.

time_offset.title: Configure Time Offset
time_offset.description:
Configure how far back in time this view should travel.

**Recommended:** Use **‚â•2 days** offset to avoid conflicts with "yesterday" entities that also provide historical data.

**Examples:**
‚Ä¢ **-7 days**: View prices from 7 days ago
‚Ä¢ **-2 days, 3 hours**: View prices from 2 days and 3 hours ago
‚Ä¢ **-14 days**: View prices from 2 weeks ago

data_description.virtual_time_offset_days: How many days to travel back in time. Slider range: 0 to 374 days (‚âà1 year). Recommended: ‚â•2 days to avoid conflicts with "yesterday" entities.
data_description.time_offset: Optional fine-tuning: Add hours and/or minutes to the day offset. The time will be automatically subtracted (travel back further). Note: Seconds are ignored - only minute-level precision is supported.

init.title: Reconfigure Time Offset
init.description: Update the time offset for this time-travel view.

data_description.virtual_time_offset_days: How many days to travel back in time. Slider range: 0 to 374 days (‚âà1 year). Recommended: ‚â•2 days to avoid conflicts with "yesterday" entities.
data_description.time_offset: Optional fine-tuning: Add hours and/or minutes to the day offset. The time will be automatically subtracted (travel back further). Note: Seconds are ignored - only minute-level precision is supported.

error.no_time_offset: At least one time offset value must be negative (historical data only).

abort.already_configured:
**A time-travel view with this exact time offset already exists.**

Please choose a different offset.
abort.no_main_entries: No main configuration entries found. Please add a Tibber home first.

init.title: ‚öôÔ∏è General Settings
init.description:
_{step_progress}_

**Configure general settings for Tibber Price Information & Ratings.**

---

**User:** {user_login}

data_description.extended_descriptions:
Controls whether entity attributes include detailed explanations and usage tips.

‚Ä¢ Disabled (default): Brief description only
‚Ä¢ Enabled: Detailed explanation + practical usage examples

Example:
Disabled = 1 attribute
Enabled = 2 additional attributes

current_interval_price_rating.title: üìä Price Rating Thresholds
current_interval_price_rating.description:
_{step_progress}_

**Configure thresholds for price rating levels (low/normal/high) based on comparison with trailing 24-hour average.**

---

data_description.price_rating_threshold_low: Percentage below the trailing 24-hour average that the current price must be to qualify as 'low' rating. Example: 5 means at least 5% below average. Sensors with this rating indicate favorable time windows. Default: 5%
data_description.price_rating_threshold_high: Percentage above the trailing 24-hour average that the current price must be to qualify as 'high' rating. Example: 10 means at least 10% above average. Sensors with this rating warn about expensive time windows. Default: 10%

best_price.title: üíö Best Price Period Settings
best_price.description:
_{step_progress}_

**Configure settings for the Best Price Period binary sensor. This sensor is active during periods with the lowest electricity prices.**

---

data_description.best_price_min_period_length: Minimum duration for a period to be considered as 'best price'. Longer periods are more practical for running appliances like dishwashers or heat pumps. Best price periods require 60 minutes minimum (vs. 30 minutes for peak price warnings) because they should provide meaningful time windows for consumption planning, not just brief opportunities.
data_description.best_price_flex: Maximum above the daily minimum price that intervals can be and still qualify as 'best price'. Recommended: 15-20 with relaxation enabled (default), or 25-35 without relaxation. Maximum: 50 (hard cap for reliable period detection).
data_description.best_price_min_distance_from_avg: Ensures periods are significantly cheaper than the daily average, not just marginally below it. This filters out noise and prevents marking slightly-below-average periods as 'best price' on days with flat prices. Higher values = stricter filtering (only truly cheap periods qualify). Default: 5 means periods must be at least 5% below the daily average.
data_description.best_price_max_level: Only show best price periods if they contain intervals with price levels ‚â§ selected value. For example, selecting 'Cheap' means the period must have at least one 'VERY_CHEAP' or 'CHEAP' interval. This ensures 'best price' periods are not just relatively cheap for the day, but actually cheap in absolute terms. Select 'Any' to show best prices regardless of their absolute price level.
data_description.best_price_max_level_gap_count: Maximum number of consecutive intervals allowed that deviate by exactly one level step from the required level. For example: with 'Cheap' filter and gap count 1, a sequence 'CHEAP, CHEAP, NORMAL, CHEAP' is accepted (NORMAL is one step above CHEAP). This prevents periods from being split by occasional level deviations. **Note:** Gap tolerance requires periods ‚â•90 minutes (6 intervals) to detect outliers effectively. Default: 0 (strict filtering, no tolerance).
data_description.enable_min_periods_best: When enabled, filters will be gradually relaxed if not enough periods are found. This attempts to reach the desired minimum number of periods, which may include less optimal time windows as best-price periods.
data_description.min_periods_best: Minimum number of best price periods to aim for per day. Filters will be relaxed step-by-step to try achieving this count. Only active when 'Try to Achieve Minimum Period Count' is enabled. Default: 1
data_description.relaxation_attempts_best: How many flex levels (attempts) to try before giving up. Each attempt runs all filter combinations at the new flex level. More attempts increase the chance of finding additional periods at the cost of longer processing time.

peak_price.title: üî¥ Peak Price Period Settings
peak_price.description:
_{step_progress}_

**Configure settings for the Peak Price Period binary sensor. This sensor is active during periods with the highest electricity prices.**

---

data_description.peak_price_min_period_length: Minimum duration for a period to be considered as 'peak price'. Peak price warnings are allowed for shorter periods (30 minutes minimum vs. 60 minutes for best price) because brief expensive spikes are worth alerting about, even if they're too short for consumption planning.
data_description.peak_price_flex: Maximum below the daily maximum price that intervals can be and still qualify as 'peak price'. Recommended: -15 to -20 with relaxation enabled (default), or -25 to -35 without relaxation. Maximum: -50 (hard cap for reliable period detection). Note: Negative values indicate distance below maximum.
data_description.peak_price_min_distance_from_avg: Ensures periods are significantly more expensive than the daily average, not just marginally above it. This filters out noise and prevents marking slightly-above-average periods as 'peak price' on days with flat prices. Higher values = stricter filtering (only truly expensive periods qualify). Default: 5 means periods must be at least 5% above the daily average.
data_description.peak_price_min_level: Only show peak price periods if they contain intervals with price levels ‚â• selected value. For example, selecting 'Expensive' means the period must have at least one 'EXPENSIVE' or 'VERY_EXPENSIVE' interval. This ensures 'peak price' periods are not just relatively expensive for the day, but actually expensive in absolute terms. Select 'Any' to show peak prices regardless of their absolute price level.
data_description.peak_price_max_level_gap_count: Maximum number of consecutive intervals allowed that deviate by exactly one level step from the required level. For example: with 'Expensive' filter and gap count 2, a sequence 'EXPENSIVE, NORMAL, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE' is accepted (NORMAL is one step below EXPENSIVE). This prevents periods from being split by occasional level deviations. **Note:** Gap tolerance requires periods ‚â•90 minutes (6 intervals) to detect outliers effectively. Default: 0 (strict filtering, no tolerance).
data_description.enable_min_periods_peak: When enabled, filters will be gradually relaxed if not enough periods are found. This attempts to reach the desired minimum number of periods to ensure you're warned about expensive periods even on days with unusual price patterns.
data_description.min_periods_peak: Minimum number of peak price periods to aim for per day. Filters will be relaxed step-by-step to try achieving this count. Only active when 'Try to Achieve Minimum Period Count' is enabled. Default: 1
data_description.relaxation_attempts_peak: How many flex levels (attempts) to try before giving up. Each attempt runs all filter combinations at the new flex level. More attempts increase the chance of finding additional peak periods at the cost of longer processing time.

price_trend.title: üìà Price Trend Thresholds
price_trend.description:
_{step_progress}_

**Configure thresholds for price trend sensors. These sensors compare current price with the average of the next N hours to determine if prices are rising, falling, or stable.**

---

data_description.price_trend_threshold_rising: Percentage that the average of the next N hours must be above the current price to qualify as 'rising' trend. Example: 5 means average is at least 5% higher ‚Üí prices will rise. Typical values: 5-15%. Default: 5%
data_description.price_trend_threshold_falling: Percentage (negative) that the average of the next N hours must be below the current price to qualify as 'falling' trend. Example: -5 means average is at least 5% lower ‚Üí prices will fall. Typical values: -5 to -15%. Default: -5%

chart_data_export.title: üìä Chart Data Export Sensor
chart_data_export.description:
_{step_progress}_

The Chart Data Export Sensor provides price data as sensor attributes.

‚ö†Ô∏è **Note:** This sensor is a legacy feature for compatibility with older tools.

**Recommended for new setups:** Use the `tibber_prices.get_chartdata` **service directly** - it's more flexible, efficient, and the modern Home Assistant approach.

**When this sensor makes sense:**

‚úÖ Your dashboard tool can **only** read attributes (no service calls)
‚úÖ You need static data that updates automatically
‚ùå **Not for automations:** Use `tibber_prices.get_chartdata` directly there - more flexible and efficient!

---

**Enable the sensor:**

1. Open **Settings ‚Üí Devices & Services ‚Üí Tibber Prices**
2. Select your home ‚Üí Find **'Chart Data Export'** (Diagnostic section)
3. **Enable the sensor** (disabled by default)

**Configuration (optional):**

Default settings work out-of-the-box (today+tomorrow, 15-minute intervals, prices only).

For customization, add to **`configuration.yaml`**:

```yaml
tibber_prices:
  chart_export:
    day:
      - today
      - tomorrow
    include_level: true
    include_rating_level: true
```

**All parameters:** See `tibber_prices.get_chartdata` service documentation

volatility.title: üí® Price Volatility Thresholds
volatility.description:
_{step_progress}_

**Configure thresholds for volatility classification.** Volatility measures relative price variation using the coefficient of variation (CV = standard deviation / mean √ó 100%). These thresholds are percentage values that work across all price levels.

Used by:
‚Ä¢ Volatility sensors (classification)
‚Ä¢ Trend sensors (adaptive threshold adjustment: <moderate = more sensitive, ‚â•high = less sensitive)

---

data_description.volatility_threshold_moderate: Coefficient of Variation (CV) at which prices are considered 'moderately volatile'. CV = (standard deviation / mean) √ó 100%. Example: 15 means price fluctuations of ¬±15% around average. Sensors show this classification, trend sensors become more sensitive. Default: 15%
data_description.volatility_threshold_high: Coefficient of Variation (CV) at which prices are considered 'highly volatile'. Example: 30 means price fluctuations of ¬±30% around average. Larger price jumps expected, trend sensors become less sensitive. Default: 30%
data_description.volatility_threshold_very_high: Coefficient of Variation (CV) at which prices are considered 'very highly volatile'. Example: 50 means extreme price fluctuations of ¬±50% around average. On such days, strong price spikes are likely. Default: 50%

error.auth: The Tibber Access Token is invalid.
error.connection: Unable to connect to Tibber. Please check your internet connection.
error.unknown: An unexpected error occurred. Please check the logs for details.
error.different_home: The access token is not valid for the home ID this integration is configured for.
error.invalid_period_length: Period length must be at least 15 minutes (multiples of 15).
error.invalid_flex: Flexibility percentage must be between -50% and +50%
error.invalid_best_price_distance: Distance percentage must be between -50% and 0% (negative = below average)
error.invalid_peak_price_distance: Distance percentage must be between 0% and 50% (positive = above average)
error.invalid_min_periods: Minimum periods count must be between 1 and 10
error.invalid_gap_count: Gap count must be between 0 and 8
error.invalid_relaxation_attempts: Relaxation attempts must be between 1 and 12
error.invalid_price_rating_low: Low price rating threshold must be between -50% and -5%
error.invalid_price_rating_high: High price rating threshold must be between 5% and 50%
error.invalid_price_rating_thresholds: Low threshold must be less than high threshold
error.invalid_volatility_threshold_moderate: Moderate volatility threshold must be between 5% and 25%
error.invalid_volatility_threshold_high: High volatility threshold must be between 20% and 40%
error.invalid_volatility_threshold_very_high: Very high volatility threshold must be between 35% and 80%
error.invalid_volatility_thresholds: Thresholds must be in ascending order: moderate < high < very high
error.invalid_price_trend_rising: Rising trend threshold must be between 1% and 50%
error.invalid_price_trend_falling: Falling trend threshold must be between -50% and -1%

new_homes_available.title: New Tibber homes detected
new_homes_available.description: We detected {count} new home(s) on your Tibber account: {homes}. You can add them to Home Assistant through the Tibber integration configuration.

homes_removed.title: Tibber homes removed
homes_removed.description: We detected that {count} home(s) have been removed from your Tibber account: {homes}. Please review your Tibber integration configuration.

get_price.name: Get Price Data
get_price.description: Fetch price data for a specific time range with automatic routing. Development and testing service for the price_info_for_range API function. Automatically uses PRICE_INFO, PRICE_INFO_RANGE, or both based on the time range boundary.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

start_time.name: Start Time
start_time.description: Start of the time range (inclusive, timezone-aware).

end_time.name: End Time
end_time.description: End of the time range (exclusive, timezone-aware).

get_apexcharts_yaml.name: Get ApexCharts Card YAML
get_apexcharts_yaml.description: Returns a ready-to-copy YAML snippet for an ApexCharts card visualizing Tibber Prices for the selected day. Use this to easily add a pre-configured chart to your dashboard. The YAML will use the get_chartdata service for data.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

day.name: Day
day.description: Which day to visualize (yesterday, today, or tomorrow).

level_type.name: Level Type
level_type.description: Select which price level classification to visualize: 'rating_level' (low/normal/high based on your configured thresholds) or 'level' (Tibber API levels: very cheap/cheap/normal/expensive/very expensive).

get_chartdata.name: Get Chart Data
get_chartdata.description: Returns price data in a simple chart-friendly format compatible with the Tibber Core integration output structure. Perfect for use with popular chart cards like ha-price-timeline-card, ApexCharts Card, Plotly Graph Card, Mini Graph Card, or the built-in History Graph Card. Field names and data structure can be customized to match your specific chart requirements.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

day.name: Day
day.description: Which day(s) to fetch prices for. You can select multiple days. If not specified, returns all available data (today + tomorrow if available).

resolution.name: Resolution
resolution.description: Time resolution for the returned data. Options: 'interval' (default, 15-minute intervals, 96 points per day), 'hourly' (hourly averages, 24 points per day).

output_format.name: Output Format
output_format.description: Output format for the returned data. Options: 'array_of_objects' (default, array of objects with customizable field names), 'array_of_arrays' (array of [timestamp, price] arrays with trailing null point for stepline charts).

array_fields.name: Array Fields (Array of Arrays only)
array_fields.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Arrays FORMAT] Define which fields to include. Use field names in curly braces, separated by commas. Available fields: start_time, price_per_kwh, level, rating_level, average. Fields will be automatically enabled even if include_* options are not set. Leave empty for default (timestamp and price only).

minor_currency.name: Minor Currency
minor_currency.description: Return prices in minor currency units (cents for EUR, √∏re for NOK/SEK) instead of major currency units. Disabled by default.

round_decimals.name: Round Decimals
round_decimals.description: Number of decimal places to round prices to (0-10). If not specified, uses default precision (4 decimals for major currency, 2 for minor currency).

include_level.name: Include Level (Array of Objects only)
include_level.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Include the Tibber price level field (VERY_CHEAP, CHEAP, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE, VERY_EXPENSIVE) in each data point.

include_rating_level.name: Include Rating Level (Array of Objects only)
include_rating_level.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Include the calculated rating level field (LOW, NORMAL, HIGH) based on your configured thresholds in each data point.

include_average.name: Include Average (Array of Objects only)
include_average.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Include the daily average price in each data point for comparison.

level_filter.name: Level Filter
level_filter.description: Filter intervals to include only specific Tibber price levels (VERY_CHEAP, CHEAP, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE, VERY_EXPENSIVE). If not specified, all levels are included.

rating_level_filter.name: Rating Level Filter
rating_level_filter.description: Filter intervals to include only specific rating levels (LOW, NORMAL, HIGH). If not specified, all rating levels are included.

period_filter.name: Period Filter
period_filter.description: Filter intervals to include only those within Best Price or Peak Price periods. Options: 'best_price' (only intervals in Best Price periods), 'peak_price' (only intervals in Peak Price periods). If not specified, all intervals are included. This uses the precomputed period data from binary sensors.

insert_nulls.name: Insert NULL Values
insert_nulls.description: Control NULL value insertion for filtered data. 'none' (default): No NULL values, only matching intervals. 'segments': Add NULL points at segment boundaries for clean gaps in charts (recommended for stepline charts). 'all': Insert NULL for all timestamps where filter doesn't match (useful for continuous time series visualization).

connect_segments.name: Connect Segments
connect_segments.description: [ONLY WITH insert_nulls='segments'] When enabled, adds connecting points at segment boundaries to visually connect different price level segments in stepline charts. When price goes DOWN at a boundary, adds a point with the lower price at the end of the current segment. When price goes UP, adds a hold point before the gap. This creates smooth visual transitions between segments instead of abrupt gaps.

add_trailing_null.name: Add Trailing Null Point
add_trailing_null.description: [BOTH FORMATS] Add a final data point with null values (except timestamp) at the end. Some chart libraries need this to prevent extrapolation/interpolation to the viewport edge when using stepline rendering. Leave disabled unless your chart requires it.

start_time_field.name: Start Time Field Name (Array of Objects only)
start_time_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the start time field in the output. Defaults to 'start_time' if not specified.

end_time_field.name: End Time Field Name (Array of Objects only)
end_time_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the end time field in the output. Defaults to 'end_time' if not specified. Only used with period_filter.

price_field.name: Price Field Name (Array of Objects only)
price_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the price field in the output. Defaults to 'price_per_kwh' if not specified.

level_field.name: Level Field Name (Array of Objects only)
level_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the level field in the output. Defaults to 'level' if not specified. Only used when include_level is enabled.

rating_level_field.name: Rating Level Field Name (Array of Objects only)
rating_level_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the rating_level field in the output. Defaults to 'rating_level' if not specified. Only used when include_rating_level is enabled.

average_field.name: Average Field Name (Array of Objects only)
average_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the average field in the output. Defaults to 'average' if not specified. Only used when include_average is enabled.

data_key.name: Data Key (both formats)
data_key.description: [BOTH FORMATS] Custom name for the top-level data key in the response. Defaults to 'data' if not specified. For ApexCharts compatibility with Array of Arrays, use 'points'.

refresh_user_data.name: Refresh User Data
refresh_user_data.description: Forces a refresh of the user data (homes, profile information) from the Tibber API. This can be useful after making changes to your Tibber account or when troubleshooting connectivity issues.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

options.new_token: Add new Tibber account API token

options.level: Tibber Level (very cheap to very expensive)
